awd_titl_txt: Developing Metallacrown Scaffolds for Luminescence, Magnetism and Supramolecular Chemistry
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamic & Mechanism B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Vincent Pecoraro of the Department of Chemistry at the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor is developing new classes of metallamacrocylic complexes called metallacrowns.  These classes of complexes exhibit technologically important properties in magnetism and imaging.  They have potential applications in near-infrared luminescent sensors, inorganic light emitting diodes and bar code labels, and quantum computing.  The imaging agents are patentable and discussions are underway for licensing for cell fixation and necrosis assays.  The project lies at the interface of organic, inorganic, and biological chemistry.  It is well suited to the education of scientists at all levels and across international boundaries.  It also serves as the basis for a Marie Curie International Research Staff Exchange Scheme program that brings junior scientists across Europe to the US for training and students from Professor Vincent Pecoraro's group to Europe. Outreach activities involving K-12 students and for students underrepresented in science are also part of the funded project.  

Metallacrowns display a rich array of photophysical properties, including the highest reported quantum yields and brightness for molecular Lanthanide complexes emitting in the near infrared spectral region. In addition, binuclear lanthanides encapsulated within diamagnetic metallacrowns show energy gaps that are appropriate for exploitation as qubits for the development of quantum computers. The proposed work exploits these properties to generate luminescent dendrimers and Janus dendrimers for imaging applications. The simple metallacrown motif will also be used as nodes to develop luminescent metal organic frameworks that may be used for sensing applications. These studies broaden the range of synthetic possibilities for both dendrimers and metal organic frameworks by leading to new structure types with either magnetic or luminescent properties.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The outcomes from NSF CHE 1664964: Developing Metallacrown Scaffolds for Luminescence, Magnetism and Supramolecular Chemistry have been both productive and enriching. During this grant, 14 papers and 2 book chapters have been published and 5 patents have been granted. Significant results that deepen knowledge in the fields of lanthanide (Ln) based luminescence, metallacrown (MC) functionalization, nanocapsule preparation and magnetic refrigeration have been achieved.

For the lanthanide luminescence, a new class of bimodal near infrared and X-ray contrast imaging agent was developed. Those metallacrowns are composed of iodine-bearing ligands and could be of great interest for biological imaging. They are 20 to 40 times more efficient than the commercially available iobitridol and additionally provide luminescence in the near infrared. In another system, two complexes of Sm3+ and Tb3+ were paired together to provide a nanothermometer in which the intensity of the emitted light can be modulated by temperature change. This would allow sub-micron temperature reading which would be very useful in cellular imaging. For another series of Dy3+ complexes, the crystal field was finely tuned to access ideal white light emission. White light emission is usually achieved by mixing different sources of light. The development of those single white light emitting compounds would find many applications in the field of material science where it could lead to more straightforward manufacturing processes.

As reported previously, metallacrowns have shown great potential as Ln-based luminescence imaging probes. To improve their aqueous solubility and biocompatibility, the ligands in the dimeric Ln2Ga8 metallacrown were modified to allow their functionalization. The addition of thiol dendrons of different generations on the bridge ligand led to toroidal-shaped metallacrowns. Those metallacrowns displayed increased solution stability in mixed aqueous/organic media while further improving their luminescent properties. The more challenging addition of those same thiol dendrons on the ring ligands provided hyperboloidal-shaped metallacrowns which also displayed increased luminescent properties. Moreover, the functionalization of the meta position of the ring ligand allowed for red-shifted excitation, which is very desirable for biological application as it is less destructive to living organisms. Taking advantage of the two different functionalization sites, asymmetric coupling was investigated by reacting biotin and thiol dendrons on the different sites. The obtained Janus dendrimers displayed similar redshifted and increased luminescent properties. The biotin was chosen as a proof of principle that functionalized metallacrowns could be further reacted with streptavidin and be used as luminescent targeting probes.

Development in the field of catalytic applications was pursued by assessing the reactivity of MC towards dicarboxylate guests. Those complexes are designed to have only one face interacting with dicarboxylate guests, leading to the formation of MC-guest-MC nanocapsules stabilized by interactions between hydrophobic carbon-based side chains. The studies showed that only the intermediate sized lanthanides (e. g., Eu, Gd and Dy) were able to form MC-muconate-MC nanocapsules, while the smaller and larger lanthanides only displayed MC-muconate interactions. To further improve the formation of nanocapsules, two MCs incorporating a single functionalized side arm were covalently linked to form MC dimers. While their purification remains challenging, they displayed formation of nanocapsules incorporating dicarboxylate guests (muconate, 2,6-naphthalene dicarboxylate) to form MC2-guest (2:1) and MC2-guest2 (2:2) adducts. Research in this area has led to greater understanding of the role of the lanthanide in guest sequestration and will influence further research in the use of metallocavitands as size-limited, unique chemical environments.

Lastly, several complexes (Gd-Fe, Gd-Mn and Dy-Mn) were studied for their magnetic properties, including the magnetocaloric effect. Those complexes are of great interest as they could provide for cheap materials that could act as magnetorefrigerants at very low temperatures. The developing technique of magnetic field dependent luminescence was also applied to a YbZn16 complex to provide insights on how the crystal field influences the mixing of electronic microstates in lanthanide ions.

During this grant, three PhD students graduated and one more will graduate soon. One postdoc was trained for a year in our laboratory. This project also involved a significant amount of international collaboration with research groups based in Poland, France, Portugal and Italy. Three students from Italy have worked at the University of Michigan to complete the required laboratory work for their master's degree. Four researchers from Poland, China and France have also spent time working on metallacrowns within our research group. One of our graduate students performed advanced magnetic measurements in France and luminescence measurements in Portugal. Two of our graduate students attended an advance short course on biological imaging in France. This international mobility of researchers allowed for fruitful exchange of ideas that were very beneficial to the project and to their academic education. The collaboration has not been restricted to international laboratories but was also conducted in the United States. One undergraduate student was trained in our laboratory and on biological imaging in collaboration with an MD/PhD at the University of Michigan Medical School.


Last Modified: 12/14/2021
Modified by: Vincent L Pecoraro
